ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned Hebrew in the past tense this semester, which was honestly really valuable for my speaking skills. You never realize how much you talk about things that have happened in the past until you try to say it in another language you don't know.
I learned more about how to conjugate verbs in the past tense and more complex vocab words.
Hebrew words and sentence construction, the Hebrew past tense
I learned Hebrew past tense and vocab for daily life
Learned how to conjugate most verbs in the past tense, as well as lots of new vocabulary.
Learned past tense
By taking this course, I added more Hebrew words to my vocabulary, and improved my reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills.
I improved my Hebrew speaking skills, while simultaneously increasing my vocabulary and learning how to conjugate verbs in the past tense.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of this course is just how small the sections are and how intense the materials are. Even though it can seem overwhelming in the moment, I really came out learning something and that I was not ignored by the professor as may have been the case in a larger section.

This course was fun; I enjoyed the social, energetic style in which it was taught. However, the organization of the canvas page was somewhat confusing; the padlet system we used for homework last semester was much better.

Strengths: can be fun, interesting supplementary material 

Weaknesses: Not enough homework practice to ingrain material, online tests disincentivize actually learning the new vocabulary and concepts, overall could feel too laid back to help you make progress
More work and more speaking

The strength is that of most language classes: daily practice. Unfortunately, this course was very weak in a few important ways. First, its organization: assignments were splattered around many confusing canvas pages which often linked back to each other, and it was painfully easy to miss one by not knowing it existed. Second, enforcement of learning the material: because there was very little work and no in-person examination, most vocabulary just fell through the cracks of everyones mind.

Strengths: similar structure to L1, Professor Orit is generally understanding and will be there to answer questions, amazing TA
Weakness: difficult organization of the class, where it's hard to remember material, low engagement
Overall, I think the class is very good and that we learn a lot over the course of the semester.

The course is very interactive, which keeps students engaged and improves speaking abilities considerably. It could be helpful to better organize the homework to make deadlines more clear for students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
I'd recommend this course to anyone wishing to learn more about the Hebrew language.
For the Hebrew track, yes. But definitely a bit of a struggle compared to L1
If they teach more and assign more homework youll learn more. If you want an easy language class, this is for you
Maybe? You cant exactly avoid taking it if youre in the sequence, but its quite badly organized. The songs and ads are always fun though!
Maybe, you would have to organize material on your own and make sure you understand on your own

Yes, if you are interested in learning Hebrew. It is not an easy language to learn so I would not take it if you are looking for an easy language credit. Otherwise, the class is very fun and I learned a lot over the semester.
Yes, I would recommend the class, as it is essential in the Hebrew-learning journey at Yale and increases skills significantly.
